awd_abstract_narration: This proposal involves a request to purchase the Fuji Bio-Imaging               Analyzer (Phosphorimager), a new device for the detection and                   quantitation of radioactivity used in a variety of biochemical                  experiments.  The quantitative capabilities of this instrument will             allow biochemical experiments not currently possible. The primary               advantages of this technology over conventional autoradiography                 using x-ray film are an increased linear response, dynamic range,               and sensitivity, as well as reduced exposure time.  The instrument              provides quantitative data from experiments involving the use of                this radioisotopes such as 32P, 35S, 14C, and 125I.  An instrument of           this type is not currently available at the Whitehead Institute.                The quantitation of radioactive samples will be carried out by the              user groups in a variety of biochemical and molecular biology                   experiment detailed in Section 8.  The technology involves the use              of storage phosphor screens which store energy form sample beta                 particle emission.  This emission is detected by the instrument and             stored on a computer hard disk.  The data can then be accessed and              analyzed using a software package provided with the instrument.  A              number of quantitative biochemical experiments not currently                    possible will be feasible because the Phosphorimager is vastly                  superior to X-ray film autoradiography.
